cwe_description: The software reads data past the end, or before the beginning, of an intended buffer. This can lead to crashes, information disclosure, or execution of arbitrary code.
explanation: The code reads pps_id from the bitstream and uses it to access avc->pps[pps_id]. It then retrieves sps_id from the resulting si->pps structure. This sps_id is subsequently used as an index to access avc->sps[si->pps->sps_id]. There is no bounds check on the value of si->pps->sps_id before it is used as an array index. An attacker could craft a malicious bitstream where sps_id is an out-of-bounds value, leading to an out-of-bounds read from the avc->sps array. This can result in a denial of service (crash) or information disclosure.

cwe_description: The software reads data past the end, or before the beginning, of the intended buffer. This can lead to crashes or information disclosure.
explanation: The code is vulnerable to an out-of-bounds read. The value of `si->pps->sps_id` is used as an index into the `avc->sps` array without any prior bounds validation. While `pps_id` is checked, `si->pps->sps_id` is derived from the parsed PPS structure, which itself is controlled by the input bitstream. An attacker could craft a malicious bitstream where `si->pps->sps_id` is an out-of-range value, leading to an out-of-bounds read from `avc->sps`. This can result in a denial of service (application crash) or potentially information disclosure.
